title: When will a SARS-CoV-2 variant other than Delta next represent more than 70.0% of total COVID-19 cases in the US?
possible_answers: A two-week period ending 25 September 2021 or earlier
A two-week period ending between 9 October 2021 and 20 November 2021
A one-week period ending between 27 November 2021 and 15 January 2022
A one-week period ending between 22 January 2022 and 12 March 2022
correct_answer: A one-week period ending between 27 November 2021 and 15 January 2022

Keeping in mind the most recent studies about omicron being 2x more transmissible than delta covid variant: delta first appeared in US in March 2021 and reached 50% of covid cases by July 3rd 2021 (roughly 4 months to 50% of covid cases). If omicron is 2x more transmissible than delta (and using delta’s doubling rate as a model), the estimated time to 70% of cases being omicron is ~mid march. However, reports in UK and Denmark state the doubling rate of omicron variant cases is 2.5 days, with an estimate of 50% of covid cases consisting of omicron variant within the next two to four weeks (as of Dec 9, so by January 9th). First case was found Nov 27th (UK) and Dec 1 (US).  To further drill down, as of Dec 16th omicron is 3% of cases in US with an estimated doubling rate of 2-3 days. Based on this model, the earliest we reach over 70% is Dec 27th and latest is Dec 30th. Using this method, the estimate based on the NY Times Denmark article seems most likely (end of Dec to mid January).   https://www.healthline.com/health-news/delta-variant-went-from-causing-10-to-over-50-of-covid-19-cases-what-happens-now https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/14/who-says-omicron-is-spreading-at-a-rate-not-seen-with-any-other-covid-variant.html https://www.news.com.au/world/coronavirus/health/what-makes-omicron-more-infectious-new-study-provides-possible-answer/news-story/9786a8ce08cf51683d651bcae9f12f2f https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2021/12/15/1064597592/a-tantalizing-clue-to-why-omicron-is-spreading-so-quickly https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/09/the-uk-braces-for-1-million-omicron-cases-as-covid-variant-spreads.html https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/13/health/omicron-cases-denmark-norway.html

Nowcast has omicron prevlance at 2.9%. CDC's stated 95% confidence interval has lower bound at 0.2% and upper at 14.7%. I want to know what current prevalence would result in >70% by Jan 12, the middle of the final week. From December 14 to Jan 12 is 29 days.  Doubling time is allegedly 3 days. (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/03/health/coronavirus-omicron-vaccines-contagiousness.html, https://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/read-this/uk-omicron-covid-cases-doubling-every-three-days-top-scientists-say-3485212) Conservatively, assume 3.5 days to double.
x*2^(29/3.5) = 0.70
x = 0.2% Conveniently this is right at the CDC's lower 95% confidence interval. So we can say with confidence that if doubling time is 3.5 days and the CDC's confidence interval can be trusted, there is exactly a 95% chance that we reach 70% prevalence in the middle of the final week of bucket 3. These are very conservative assumptions. Likely doubling time is lower than 3.5 days since the media is saying 3 days. It also seems implausible that we would only be at 0.2% omicron prevalence given what other countries are seeing. I'm quite confident that we are much higher, and we can be more certain than 95% that the current prevalence is above 0.2%. i'll put it at 99%

updating based on @belikewater 's comments. I ran my own analysis to check and now expect Omicron to hit the 70% threshold in late December / early January. In the back of my mind, the thing I could imagine that would prevent Omicron from hitting this threshold would be another highly fit variant competing with it, but I consider this an unlikely event.

There have been several sources of uncertainty for this question: the current percentage of cases that are Omicron, the doubling time, and what Delta is going to do. I think we can safely say that Delta cases likely won't go above a 7-day average of 200k/day in January and will probably peak somewhere around 150k/day. Omicron's doubling time has been estimated at 3.7 days in the US on Dec 1, with r=0.19: https://twitter.com/trvrb/status/1469784769273622530
What's left? The current percentage of cases that are Omicron. The CDC's "Nowcast" data (part of the question resolution data) just came out for the week ending Dec 11 and estimates the percentage of cases due to Omicron for that week at 2.9%, range 0.2% to 14.7%. In a previous version of this question, we all noticed that the Nowcast numbers tend to get revised upwards over the following week or 2; there is considerable uncertainty. I think 0.2% is extremely unlikely based on the data we already have; I will guess that this estimate will ultimately be revised to 4-8% or so. But the outcome of this question is obviously highly dependent on the seeding number now. So, let's consider the case that 3% of cases on Dec 11 were caused by Omicron, which is a big underestimate because 2.9% of the cases for the whole previous *week* were Omicron. Even in that case, bin 3 looks all but certain now, as Omicron would be predicted to overtake Delta even before the end of the year. As in, with Delta cases continuing to grow towards a peak of, say, 150k-200k/day in early January, Omicron can be expected to overtake Delta before the end of the year (ignoring the dip in reporting over the holiday, which will reduce reporting proportionately for all cases). Unless a lot of mitigations are put in place and fast, and I don't think they will be, I think we're soon going to see the biggest surge in cases yet.

Even the late-to-the-party CDC data tracker is now reporting a best estimate of US Omicron proportions for the “week ending 12/11” of 2.9% (upper bound 14.7%!!). Up from 0.0% (upper bound 0.0%) in the previous week.

gisaid reported 20 more U.S. confirmed Omicron cases today [1]. There is a lag in reporting, and so assign these 20 cases to a week ago (December 4th). Doubling daily cases every 3 days, Omicron daily confirmed cases could reach 200,000 on January 13th. Add in a constant 120,000 Delta daily cases, and calculate weekly percent Omicron share:
December 19 to 25: 1% Omicron share
December 26 to January 1: 6% Omicron share
January 2 to 8: 23% Omicron share
January 9 to 15: 60% Omicron share
January 16 to 22: 88% Omicron share
January 23 to 29: 97% Omicron share Combining these weekly numbers into 2-week periods could be done two different ways: a straight average or a weighted average (assuming twice as many weekly cases in the second week).
January 2 to 15: straight average 41% Omicron share. ((23+60)/2)
January 2 to 15: weighted average 48% Omicron share.  ((23+60*2)/3) The question should be answered using a weighted average (using the actual weekly cases).  This calculation has 70% Omicron share for the 2-week period ending January 19th. This could be delayed because of reactions to the rapidly rising cases, or because there are fewer social events in the first few weeks of January. 1. https://www.gisaid.org/hcov19-variants/

I think it would be very difficult for any variant to overtake Delta in the CDC data (which would require >70.0% of all sequences in a 2-week period to be of a non-Delta lineage) by Jan 15. Omicron or whatever would need to go from 0% to 70% in 6 weeks. If Delta continues to surge through early January, that's not going to happen. Otoh, if Delta winds down this month, it's still possible. However, I don't think it's likely that Delta will wind down to low levels by the end of December; I suspect it'll still be going at least fairly strong and will likely peak in early January, like last year. So, I think bin 3 has a very low probability. Bin 4 is much more likely, imo. But when Delta winds down, more than one variant may arise at the same time. Omicron will likely spread regardless of what Delta is doing and will likely co-circulate just fine; I don't think it will "replace" Delta in any meaningful way. Other variants that escape more or less existing antibody immunity may also start to be visible by bin 4. It's likely that one will do better than the rest, but by how much? I think it's a near certainty that Delta will represent <50% of cases by sometime in bin 4, but it's not clear yet whether one variant will emerge to cause >70.0% of all cases.

While it is important not to jump to very firm conclusions without more data, there is enough data to cause a lot of worry, and South African health professionals are telling us to be very concerned. It's also important to remember that many downplayed Delta early on because "we didn't have enough data," when Indian health professionals told us to be concerned; we don't need to be able to draw firm conclusions to be very concerned.

Delta was dominant in India by mid-March and peaked in early May, and it became dominant in the US by mid-July and peaked in early Sept. Thus, it is conceivable to me that a variant that supersedes Delta to become dominant in SA at the end of November could spread to and within countries faster than Delta did and could become dominant in the US by mid March.
Also, note that it's possible that this variant may already be spreading at higher or similar numbers in countries other than SA. It may simply have been detected first in SA because of greater surveillance and because it is causing a surge on top of a very low baseline of Delta cases. In other countries, particularly those with greater Delta spread and/or little surveillance, it could easily go undetected for quite a while. It has been detected almost simultaneously in travelers from SA, Malawi and Egypt, once people started to look. It may be spreading fairly widely within several or many countries in Africa and has likely already spread in small numbers, undetected, to many or most countries around the world.
Also, note that it has now been shown conclusively that a new variant can become dominant in a region with low spread; no giant surge is required when a region has a low starting point.

At this point, I now assess the chances of this question's conditions being met prior to 12 March 2022 at less than 0.5%, so I am assigning a forecast that looks like "full certainty". However, my forecast wouldn't yet be 100% on the final bin if we were able to specify probabilities more precisely at the very high/low end of the probability scale. (The average American's probability of being in a car accident next year surely far exceeds the probability of them winning the lottery (if they play), and yet both of those meaningfully distinguishable, non-zero probabilities should presumably be most accurately represented in the GJO format as a "0% / 100%" yes/no forecast.) - As we are all aware, US COVID cases are on the upswing again, about to cross upwards of 100k new cases/day. Any scenario where the 70%+ criterion will be satisfied as a technicality of very small remaining case counts, correspondingly, can be safely dismissed as being exceedingly improbable. The larger the number of active Delta cases, the harder it is for a non-Delta strain to achieve the 70%+ threshold.
- There are still no new Variants of Concern beyond Delta, or even Variants of Interest, according to the WHO's variant tracker
https://www.who.int/en/activities/tracking-SARS-CoV-2-variants/
Correspondingly, the odds of a new, non-Delta variant arising now and propagating to > 70% prominence within the question timeframe are, again, exceedingly improbable (especially given the typically multi-month timeframes over which the historical new variant propagations have unfolded).
- Delta variants currently account for 99.9%+ of all currently active cases, and have "topped the charts" for a very long time now.

There are now about 500 thousand new confirmed cases in the world every day [1]. Previous troughs were about 400 thousand in February and June 2021. Projecting this, a new trough might occur in October. New variants took hold soon after the previous troughs (February trough, April Alpha variant dominant, June trough, July Delta variant dominant).  The Alpha variant was first identified in September, and in April became prevalent in the US [2].  Delta was first identified in December 2020, and in July was prevalent in the US. Both Alpha and Delta first occurred outside the US. Based on this, it might take 7 months from when a new variant is identified outside the US to US prevalence.  There are several variants of interest [3].  Lambda and Mu were discovered more than 7 months ago, and so seem unlikely to take over. There are 14 additional "designated Variants Under Monitoring", but only one was discovered recently:  C.1.2 discovered in South Africa, May 2021.  Both cases and deaths are now declining in South Africa, and so it is unlikely C.1.2 will be a problem.  I do not see any new variant first identified outside the US becoming prevalent in the US until after April 30th (7 months from now). A variant first appearing in the US will take less time to spread in the US. There are plenty of new US cases giving the virus chances to mutate (100,000 new confirmed daily cases). It took 3 months for Delta to grow from 1% to over 70% in the US (April to July). This might show up in one region first. Delta was first detected in Dec 2020 in India, gained prominence there in April, became dominant in the US in July.
Both Lambda and Mu are in the US now. If either were to become the next dominant strain, it would probably take at least 3 months to do so. But 1) neither may be fit enough, 2) there may still be enough Delta around to prevent either from reaching >70.0% of strains, and/or 3) they could compete with each other to the extent that neither becomes dominant.
I still think bin 3 is unlikely, at least for now. But I'll increase bin 3 a bit. There's really no way to know where Lambda or Mu will go at this point, but there are a few things in their favor:
1. Given all the surveillance that's happening all over the world, a strain will be identified before it starts to represent a large number of cases. Lambda and Mu have been identified.
2. More studies are needed, but it appears that Lambda and Mu are both highly transmissible and immune escape variants. Quite the analysis required here as there are a lot of moving parts. Firstly, 70% of US cases means case numbers can be anything. If Delta transmission starts to wane, we could see an uptick in another variant and hit 70% sooner than we'd expect. @Emking points out some of the complexities here in his forecast below. Secondly, we have to consider the speed at which a new variant will be formed and identified. This takes time, but the more infections we have the more compressed that timeline is. Delta was first discovered in December 2020 and it took 7 months to reach the US and hit the 70% threshold. Third, we have to consider where the next variant is going to appear. India was ripe for a variant with the speed and spread of cases. In another country, the speed of spread and ability to jump borders might be lessened. We could also have it appear here in the US with our infection numbers rising. Fourth, the number of people who can be infected (barring something that bypasses our current immunities) is dropping. Fewer people capable of being infected and spreading this means fewer people to create variants and fewer people to spread any variants. All this to say that I think it extremely unlikely that we identify another variant, get it here to the US, spread it among our population, and hit 70% infections with this all in the span of 7 months. Possible, certainly, but improbable. Prediction will be updated if a new variant is identified soon and shows itself to be very infective and/or variant(s) begin emerging within the US because that would negate the geographic hurdle which is a significant barrier to beginning the snowball.

As I've thought more about this, I'm thinking that the rival natural of these variants is important. It makes the question harder because there is dependence. For example, Delta decreasing while another strand increases (in nominal values) seems less likely than first glance - as both variants seek the same conditions for transmission. Therefore, new strand is only likely to exceed the growth rate of Delta if it is more contagious than Delta. The most likely way for that to happen is to be resistant against Delta while being susceptible to another strand. That requires two conditions - immunity and mutation, followed by spread. Therefore, I'm further reducing the near-term bins, but remaining uneasy about the potential for a new strand to spread in the Winter after Delta immunity is greatly increased by the Fall.

Also, given that we've only seen ancestral strains and Delta reach >70% since the pandemic started, it could be most reasonable to weight the last bin very high. But variants arise by the stochastic process of genetic mutation and then are selected for or against by their environment. Right now, immunity throughout the world as a whole is low enough that increased transmissibility is the dominant feature that is selected for; immune escape seems to be less important to the virus at the moment. So we can estimate that the chance of formation of new, highly transmissible variants is proportional to the number of cases in the world at any given time. Now that Delta is making its way through many places, we may start to see a peak in cases in the Norther Hemisphere Winter and a peak in the Southern Hemisphere winter. There could be peaks outside these periods if a highly contagious variant starts to spread uncontrolled in an immunologically naive population like that of China, or if a drastic immune-escape variant develops. But I'm going to hypothesize that N and S winters are going to present the greatest risk of generating new variants of relevance to this question and that these variants could spread to the US soon after generation.
